problem:
Let $S$ be the set of all point $(x,y)$ in the coordinate plane such that $0 \le x \le \frac{\pi}{2}$ and $0 \le y \le \frac{\pi}{2}$.  What is the area of the subset of $S$ for which \[\sin^2x-\sin x \sin y + \sin^2y \le \frac34?\]
$\mathrm{(A)}\ \dfrac{\pi^2}{9} \qquad \mathrm{(B)}\ \dfrac{\pi^2}{8} \qquad \mathrm{(C)}\ \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} \qquad \mathrm{(D)}\ \dfrac{3\pi^2}{16} \qquad \mathrm{(E)}\ \dfrac{2\pi^2}{9}$

solutions.Solution 2:
We can write the given equation as \[\sin^3x + \sin^3y \le \frac{3}{4}(\sin x + \sin y).\] Note that when $x = 0$, we have $\sin y \le \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ which implies $y \le \frac{\pi}{3}$. Similary we have $x \le \frac{\pi}{3}$ when $y = 0$. Then we see what happens at $x = \frac{\pi}{2}$. Clearly at $x = \frac{\pi}{2}$, we see that $y \le \frac{\pi}{6}$. By symmetry we have $x \le \frac{\pi}{6}$ when $y = \frac{\pi}{2}$. So we get a graph like 
[asy] size(5cm); D((0,0)--(3,0)--(3,3)--(0,3)--cycle); D((1,-0.1)--(1,0.1)); D((2,-0.1)--(2,0.1)); D((-0.1,1)--(0.1,1)); D((-0.1,2)--(0.1,2)); D((2,0)--(3,1)--(1,3)--(0,2)); MP("\frac{\pi}{6}", (1,0), plain.S); MP("\frac{\pi}{3}", (2,0), plain.S); MP("\frac{\pi}{2}", (3,0), plain.S); MP("\frac{\pi}{6}", (0,1), plain.W); MP("\frac{\pi}{3}", (0,2), plain.W); MP("\frac{\pi}{2}", (0,3), plain.W); [/asy]
Thus the area of what we are interested in is \[\frac{\pi^2}{4} - (\frac{\pi^2}{18} + \frac{\pi^2}{36}) = \frac{\pi^2}{6}.\]
